node.title: Tennis star Peng Shuai is the latest high-profile figure to disappear in China. But her case stands out
node.alt: Peng Shuai looks to the side while sitting at a desk for a press conference with a microphone in front of her.
node.description: Peng Shuai disappeared after making an explosive #MeToo claim about a top government official on social media. She joins a growing list of those who have gone missing.
node.content:
["Powerful billionaires, A-list celebrities\u00a0and even the Interpol chief have all disappeared in China in recent years.", "The\u00a0latest high-profile casualty is one of the country's biggest sport stars,\u00a0tennis player Peng Shuai.", "Ms Peng went missing earlier this month after claiming on social media that\u00a0a former member of China's Politburo Standing Committee, Zhang Gaoli, coerced her into sex\u00a0and that they later had an on-off consensual relationship.", "But an email published this week by\u00a0China's global TV network, CGTN, said to have been sent by Ms Peng to\u00a0Women's Tennis Association (WTA) chairman\u00a0Steve Simon, said the 35-year-old was\u00a0\"not missing, nor am I unsafe\".\u00a0", "\"I've just been resting at home and everything is fine,\" the email stated.", "The email said the allegation of sexual assault was \"not true\".", "We've seen similar scenarios play out many times before \u2013\u00a0a public figure who speaks out against the Chinese\u00a0government disappears, a public\u00a0apology or confession is released, then they reappear\u00a0only to be\u00a0fined or sentenced soon after.\u00a0", "Since President Xi Jinping came to power in 2012 there has been little room for dissent in China, and he has made it clear that no matter how rich, famous or powerful you are, no-one is beyond the reach of authorities.\u00a0", "However Ms Peng's case adds an extra layer of concern over the silencing of women and the future of the #MeToo movement that had been slowly gaining momentum in China.", "Here's a look back at how disappearances have become\u00a0the new normal and why the latest case stands out.", "", "
Alibaba founder Jack Ma is one of the many high-profile people in China who vanished after criticising the governmnet.\u00a0(Reuters:\u00a0Charles Platiau)
", "
Refining the disappearing act\u00a0
", "Disappearances can target all types of people, whether it's corrupt officials, media personalities, booksellers who distribute material critical of the government, or citizen journalists\u00a0reporting on the country's pandemic response.\u00a0", "While it's difficult to put an exact number on disappearances, China experts say that among the\u00a0Uyghur community and minority groups alone it could be upwards of a million people.", "When taking power, Mr Xi\u00a0introduced new laws that essentially made arbitrary and secret detentions legal under Chinese law.", "Regardless of citizenship, these complex laws can be used to strip detainees of their rights on the grounds of \"national security\".", "There is speculation over what happens to people when they go missing.", "For the high-profile, it may be a case of being forced to lay low, while others can be held in custody under the \"residential surveillance at a designated location\" scheme, which cuts suspects off from the outside world.", "The location for the residential\u00a0surveillance scheme\u00a0is usually a facility\u00a0run by the secret police, and can involve a person being held in solitary confinement and subjected to continuous interrogations.", "But this form of detention is usually used for those\u00a0accused of endangering state security.", "
Billionaires and celebrities targeted\u00a0
", "In recent years, the government appears to have been setting an example with high-profile figures who vanish after criticising the Communist Party and then reappear\u00a0after some time with a public punishment.\u00a0", "One of the most prominent victims was Alibaba founder Jack Ma, who went missing\u00a0three months after giving a controversial speech in late 2020 where he\u00a0blasted China's regulatory system.", "The disappearance of Mr Ma, who had been ranked by Forbes as China's richest person and was adoringly referred to by many as \"Daddy Ma\", sparked a wave of international attention.", "Mr Ma\u00a0reappeared in a short video for a charity event in\u00a0January 2021, and not long after\u00a0Alibaba was fined $US2.8 billion ($3.8 billion) for anti-competitive behaviour\u00a0along with a range of other transgressions.\u00a0\u00a0", "The once\u00a0outspoken and flamboyant figure has been keeping a low profile ever since.\u00a0", "Another well-known businessman, real estate tycoon Ren Zhiqiang,\u00a0reportedly disappeared last year after he called Mr Xi a \"clown\" for his handling of the coronavirus crisis in China.", "He was later\u00a0sentenced to 18 years in prison for corruption.", "", "
Fan Bingbing vanished for several months before agreeing to pay a fine for tax evasion.\u00a0(Reuters: Stephane Mahe)
", "In 2018, Fan Bingbing, one of China's highest-paid actresses, who\u00a0appeared in X-Men and Iron Man films, disappeared between June and October amid tax evasion allegations.\u00a0", "She later re-emerged, posting a lengthy statement on social media apologising for her actions and agreeing to pay $US167 million ($230 million) in fines.", "Celebrities are also being \"disappeared\" or silenced online.\u00a0", "Billionaire actress and filmmaker Zhao Wei, also known as Vicky Zhao, recently vanished from\u00a0many video platforms, and has had her name removed from online casting lists.", "The Global Times\u00a0ran a headline\u00a0the day after Zhao was scrubbed, calling her a \"scandals-hit actress\", detailing the various lawsuits surrounding her investments, which included an early stake in Alibaba Pictures Group, a film company under Jack Ma's Alibaba Group.", "", "
Zhao Wei\u00a0appears to have been blacklisted by the Chinese government, after her internet presence in China was scrubbed.(AFP: Eyepress News)
", "
A high-profile #MeToo silencing\u00a0\u00a0
", "While high-profile disappearances have become common, Dr Pichamon Yeophantong, a political scientist and China expert at UNSW Canberra, said Ms Peng's case stood out.", "She said that was because,\u00a0while it involved a high-level official, it also touched\u00a0on sexual harassment and\u00a0gender issues in Chinese society.", "\"Speaking up about sexual harassment or sexual assault is not something that's\u00a0part of the culture yet,\"\u00a0Dr Yeophantong told the ABC.", "Mr Xi has recently been ramping up\u00a0efforts to stamp out feminist voices\u00a0in the country.", "Terms like \"feminism\"\u00a0and \"MeToo\" are considered sensitive\u00a0and are subject to online censorship, and dozens of feminist accounts have been abruptly shut down on popular social media sites like Weibo and Douban.", "Dr\u00a0Yeophantong said there had been some growth in\u00a0grassroots women's rights movements, but much of it was still constrained by political and traditional culture, with the younger generation voicing grievances that \"there's still a sense of superficiality\".", "\"For such a tennis star to disappear, in a country that really idolises these types of individuals, it does send a very strong message that there are more constraints being imposed\u00a0on people who are in the spotlight,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
\u00a0Zhou Xiaoxuan has vowed to continue the fight despite the court's judgement.\u00a0(AP: Andy Wong)
", "The country's #MeToo movement had been gaining pace, with an\u00a0arrest in August of\u00a0one of the country's biggest pop idols, Kris Wu, on rape allegations.", "The movement was dealt a blow in September when a Beijing court ruled that\u00a0Zhou Xiaoxuan, who became the face of China's\u00a0#MeToo movement\u00a0in 2018,\u00a0did not have enough evidence in her harassment case against\u00a0one of China's most high-profile TV hosts,\u00a0Zhu Jun.", "Ms Zhou had accused Mr Zhu of groping and forcibly kissing her in a makeup room when she worked as a media intern with Chinese broadcaster CCTV in 2014.", "Dr\u00a0Yeophantong said that instead of instilling fear,\u00a0Ms Peng's case may prompt more people to\u00a0speak out.\u00a0", "\"I think that this case has the potential to energise debate on the issue and also get more Chinese women involved in the movement because it's not just a political problem, it's a social problem as well.\"\u00a0\u00a0"]
